Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979) (par.raw_text: Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979) (parental rights and state interests) (federal authority regarding parental rights);
Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979) (par.proposition: Modification of custody and parenting schedules is governed by Massachusetts law requiring a showing of a material change in circumstances and an analysis of the children’s best interests.
Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979) (par.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts family-law standards for modifying child custody and parenting schedules, specifically the requirement of a material change in circumstances and a best-interests analysis. Parham v. J.R. addresses federal due process requirements for the voluntary commitment of minors to state mental institutions and discusses parental rights and state interests in that context. It does not concern, interpret, or apply Massachusetts custody-modification law, nor does it set standards for changes in custody or parenting time, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979) (par.relevant_excerpt: "Our jurisprudence historically has reflected Western civilization concepts of the family as a unit with broad parental authority over minor children. Our cases have consistently followed that course; our constitutional system long ago rejected any notion that a child is ‘the mere creature of the State’ ... Nonetheless, we have recognized that a state is not without constitutional control over parental discretion in dealing with children when their physical or mental health is jeopardized." (Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. at 602-603)

Cleveland v. Cleveland, 375 Mass. 500 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a tax assessment/abatement case about disproportionate property tax assessments in Weymouth. It does not discuss family law, child custody, parenting schedules, or standards for modifying custody orders. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the Massachusetts custody-modification standard requiring a material change in circumstances and best-interests analysis.
Cleveland v. Cleveland, 375 Mass. 500 (1.relevant_excerpt: "In this Commonwealth it is both a constitutional and statutory requirement that real property be assessed at its full and fair cash value... In order to secure such an abatement a taxpayer must prove that the assessors have engaged in a scheme of disproportionate and discriminatory assessment."

Brown) involving evidentiary issues about confessions and confrontation rights, not a family law or custody matter. It does not discuss modification of custody, parenting schedules, material change in circumstances, or the children’s best interests. Thus it cannot serve as authority for the Massachusetts custody-modification standard described in the proposition.
Newell v. Newell, 389 Mass. 386 (1983) (.relevant_excerpt: Brown argues two points before us. First, he claims reversible error in the admission of his confessions as to crimes for which he was not on trial. Second, he claims error in the exclusion of the probable cause transcript disclosing the cross-examination of the two victims by counsel for the co-defendant Stiles.

Fortin v. Vokey, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 149 (.raw_text: Fortin v. Vokey, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 149 (1996) (parenting schedule and practical considerations);
Fortin v. Vokey, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 149 (.proposition: Modification of custody and parenting schedules is governed by Massachusetts law requiring a showing of a material change in circumstances and an analysis of the children’s best interests.
Fortin v. Vokey, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 149 (.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a civil procedure case about jury trial rights and the remand/removal system between District Court and Superior Court under G.L. c. 231, §§ 102C, 103, and 104. It does not concern family law, custody, parenting schedules, or the standards for modification of custody under Massachusetts law (material change in circumstances and best interests of the child). Therefore it does not support the cited proposition regarding modification of custody and parenting schedules.
Fortin v. Vokey, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 149 (.relevant_excerpt: Section 103 of G. L. c. 231 (see note 4, supra, for the full text), as appearing in St. 1987, c. 251, § 1, provides that a party who elects to bring in District Court an action that it might have brought in Superior Court, e.g., a claim for more than $25,000, “shall be deemed to have waived a trial by jury and [its] right of appeal to the Superior Court, unless within thirty days of commencement of the action . . . [the] plaintiff files a claim to a jury trial in the superior court with the district court ...” (emphasis supplied).
